heading: pols vie for privacy gig
subheading: the ftc passes over the usual suspects in selecting a privacy panel. plus: forbes and gore talk tech, pols debate the fcc radio initiative, firearms on the net, and more. declan mccullagh empties his notebook from washington.
author: wired staff
text: being appointed to a federal advisory committee is a lot like becoming a mother-in-law: you get to tell everyone why they're wrong, but nobody has to listen. still, resume-obsessed washingtonians vie for such opportunities, and a few dozen of them learned friday they would be on a federal trade commission privacy and security advisory panel. (the self-congratulatory press releases quickly followed.)the interesting thing, though, was how the ftc decided on the members. over 180 people applied, and about 40 were picked. you'd think that of that pool of eager applicants, the ftc would have an exquisite selection of potential choices. nope.the commission decided to pass over veteran privacy advocates and technical experts -- like systemexperts cto dan geer, a security guru and usenix officer since 1985 -- to choose someone who hadn't even applied for the gig. they picked e. david ellington, chairman and ceo of netnoir, an online services company that targets african-americans.it probably didn't hurt that ellington gave us$2,500 to democratic candidates -- including $1,000 to al gore -- during the last two years, according to federal election commission records. an ftc staff member wouldn't say why ellington was chosen except to say the commission wanted to "make its best efforts" to make sure the group was representative."the commission retained discretion in the absence of a nomination to appoint advisory committee members to ensure balance," said jessica rich, who pointed us to a federal register notice in december that said precisely that.perhaps the ftc hoped serving on the advisory panel, which first meets on 4 february, would prove educational? netnoir asks visitors for their home addresses, birthdates, and telephone numbers, but does not have a posted privacy policy saying what it will do -- or won't do -- with that info.that runs afoul of the better business bureau's principles for ethical conduct for web businesses, not to mention the ftc's own guidelines. the only other person on the panel who didn't apply was robert henderson of ncr corporation. the ftc said he replaced peter reid, also of ncr, who did apply.forbes, gore talk tech: kent lassman from the free-market group citizens for a sound economy has a hectic job: following presidential wannabes as they stump in iowa. he writes in to tell us that tech issues have been on their minds."when forbes took q & a, the local precinct captain who had given the introduction read him the riot act on internet taxation ... and he has a good position," lassman said in an email message talking about gop hopeful steve forbes.he also cornered vice president al gore."this evening gore said, 'we've got to use the antitrust laws much more aggressively.' i asked if that meant in high tech. he asked if i meant the microsoft case. i said no ... intel, microsoft, [and the] merger policy with regard to att-tci and aol-tw. 'i can't comment on a specific case. the law will take care of them.' i'm not sure what he meant."dc roundup: washington, dc's city government on thursday filed a lawsuit against gun manufacturers, claiming they create a "public nuisance" in the nation's capital, where handguns have officially been banned since 1976 and where cops unofficially advise residents in crime-plagued areas to have one in their homes.among other demands, dc mayor anthony williams wants to force gun makers to stop selling firearms using the internet.... truste ceo bob lewin held a "california wine and cheese party" in the group's washington dc digs -- the offices of law firm wiley rein and fielding -- on wednesday.... pentagon tech-bigwigs seemed to be leaving for the private sector as soon as the big y2k scare fizzled.deputy defense secretary john hamre and marv langston, deputy assistant secretary, have both given notice. hamre, you'll recall, was responsible for the dod's y2k efforts and this month talked about the problems encryption poses to the feds.... montana gop senator conrad burns waxed indignant about the fcc's decision to let smaller fm radio stations exist."the fact of the matter is that this initiative basically legalizes pirate radio stations," said the chair of the senate communications subcommittee, who neglected to mention that he's received over $380,000 in contributions from communications and electronics firms.... silicon valley ceos backing george w. flew into new hampshire this week to talk up the merits of the texas gov. they were particularly interested in net-taxes -- especially the continued absence of them -- and tort reform....speaking of net-taxes, the national conference of state legislatures this week released "model" legislation for states to approve. the idea is to allow collection of sales taxes online.... other ceos, including dell computers' michael dell, met with white house chief of staff john podesta this week to chat about chip exports.they want to do more of it, and aren't exactly pleased by government regulations. president clinton dropped by the meeting, a spokesman said....
